summary: A tutorial video guiding viewers through the process of setting up a speedrun timer using LiveSplit and integrating it with OBS.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a person wearing a dark blue shirt and headphones is seated in a room illuminated by pink and blue neon lights. They are speaking into a microphone with a picture of a laughing man on it. The background features a plant and a glowing lamp. A text overlay reads 'LiquidCandy' with a message 'Subscribe if you see this.' The scene transitions to a screen displaying a list of items from 'The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker' with their respective times, and a timer showing '10:56.48.' The person continues to speak, and text appears on the screen saying 'Also how to make it transparent.' The video then shifts to a webpage for 'LiveSplit,' a timer for speedrunners, with the person still visible in the lower part of the frame. The webpage includes sections for downloads, donations, and social media links. The person remains seated in the same room, maintaining the same attire and background throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker starting off in an excited tone, stating the listener is here for "one reason and one reason only," to understand a visual timer. The speaker transitions into a more instructive tone, saying, "Perfect. I'm going to teach you how to do it," promising to be direct. He instructs the listener, "First things first, you want to go to live split."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing a blue sweater and headphones, seated in front of a computer screen displaying the LiveSplit website, which is a timer for speedrunners. The website's interface is black with white text, showcasing sections for downloads, donations, and social media links. The person appears to be explaining or demonstrating something related to LiveSplit, as indicated by their hand gestures and facial expressions. The scene transitions to a split-screen view, showing the person on the left and a file explorer window on the right. The file explorer displays a list of files and folders, with the 'LiveSplit' folder highlighted. The person continues to interact with the computer, pointing at the file explorer and the LiveSplit website. The video progresses with the person selecting a file named 'LiveSplit.exe' from the file explorer, which is then opened in a new window. The window displays a form with fields for 'Game Title' and 'Icon,' suggesting the person is configuring settings for LiveSplit. Throughout the video, the person's actions and the on-screen text provide a clear demonstration of using LiveSplit for speedrunning purposes.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a link in the description, instructing listeners to click it, visit the page, and download. He then advises creating a new folder on the desktop and dragging the file into it. He describes opening the file and moving its contents to the new folder. Next, he instructs listeners to open LiveSplit by double-clicking an executable file, and explains that the window that appears is their timer. He moves on to opening the "edit splits" feature, introducing the next stage of the process.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing headphones and a dark blue shirt, seated in front of a computer screen displaying a file explorer window with numerous files and folders. The individual appears to be engaged in a task involving the 'Spin Editor' software, which is open on the right side of the screen. The software interface includes fields for 'Game Name,' 'Per Client,' and 'Per Server,' along with buttons for 'Send Back,' 'Send Forward,' 'Add Text,' 'Set Text Type,' 'Report Text,' and 'Send Text.' The person interacts with the software, selecting options and making adjustments. A Minecraft block graphic briefly appears in the lower right corner, adding a playful element to the scene. The background remains consistent, with the file explorer window and the 'Spin Editor' software being the primary focus. The video captures the person's actions and the software's interface, providing a clear view of the task being performed.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing steps for a game, specifically mentioning "choose the game" and typing in "Minecraft." He then mentions the "run category" as a subheading. Continuing, he explains adding the game name and category before putting in splits. Throughout this section, his tone is instructional.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a person is seated in front of a computer screen, wearing a dark blue hoodie and headphones, with a focused expression. The screen displays a file explorer window on the left side, showing various folders and files, and a 'Split Options' window on the right side, with fields for 'Game Name,' 'Per Hour Clients,' 'Per Day Clients,' and 'Revenue,' along with buttons for 'Add Text,' 'Add Time,' 'Add Time Zone,' 'Add Segment,' 'Set First Search,' and 'Set Second Search.' The 'Split Options' window also features a logo with the text 'GAMER JEAN' and a 'Previous Segment' section at the bottom. The person appears to be interacting with the 'Split Options' window, as the cursor moves and clicks on different elements. The video progresses with the addition of large, bold text overlaying the screen, reading 'OVERWORLD NETHER END PORTAL,' which seems to be related to the content being discussed or demonstrated. The environment is a typical computer setup, with a dark theme and a focus on the screen content.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker explaining the concept of breaking down a game into smaller segments to track progress. He uses a Minecraft speedrun as an example, stating they will have "four splits." He proceeds to describe the process of adding four segments and titles them "Overworld," "Nether," "End Portal Search," and "Ender Dragon," ending the segment on a neutral tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a person wearing headphones and a dark-colored hoodie is seated in front of a computer screen, which displays a software interface with various options and settings. The individual appears to be explaining or demonstrating the use of the software, which seems to be related to Minecraft, as indicated by the presence of Minecraft-related icons and folders on the left side of the screen. The person gestures with their hands, pointing at different parts of the interface, and occasionally looks at the camera, suggesting they are addressing an audience. The software interface includes a list of actions such as 'Overworld,' 'End Portal Search,' and 'Ender Dragon,' with a progress bar and a timer set to 0:00. The person navigates through the software's settings, opening and closing various windows, including one labeled 'Game Server' and another with options for 'Resource Packs,' 'Behavior Packs,' and 'Texture Packs.' The video also shows the person selecting different media options, such as 'Graph Option,' and adding other media to the interface. The background remains consistent throughout the video, with the computer screen being the primary focus, and the person's actions and gestures are the main elements of the narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins in a conversational tone, giving instructions on how to add icons to splits, stating to "double-click on this icon" and choose the file. He mentions icons he has chosen and offers them to viewers. He then discusses how to edit the layout by right-clicking and adjusting the total number of splits in the settings. Moving on, he suggests using a horizontal line instead of a small box and touches on self-explanatory settings. The speaker proposes adding 'spicy things' such as a more detailed timer, suggesting to go to the timer menu and click detailed timer and add or remove as desired. Further options for customization include adding sound effects from media, MP3 files.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person sitting in front of a computer screen, wearing a dark blue hoodie and headphones, with a small plush toy in their hand. The screen displays a Minecraft game interface with various settings and statistics visible. The person appears to be interacting with the game, adjusting settings and monitoring performance metrics. The interface shows different game modes such as Overworld, End Portal Search, and Ender Dragon, along with their respective times and scores. The person seems focused on the game, occasionally looking at the screen and making adjustments. The background is a dark desktop with several icons and folders visible, including Minecraft-related files. The video captures the person's engagement with the game, highlighting their interaction with the settings and the game's performance metrics.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining how to add hotkeys, suggesting to right-click the window and click settings, which opens a hotkeys window. He notes the first five settings are the most commonly used, but explains he will focus on the first three for the tutorial. He tells the listener how to change the hotkey, provides the example of insert, and explains how to reset and undo split. He advises selecting uncommon keys, then recommends turning on global keys to allow the same hotkeys to affect the timer, regardless of which window is in focus. The speaker encourages resizing the window and then begins to explain the different colors of the split, such as blue for finishing a speedrun, as well as positive red, minus gold, and minus green indicators, describing their meaning. He apologizes for a "stream inception" before explaining they're going to import the LiveSplit window onto their OBS scene.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing headphones, seated in front of a computer screen displaying a streaming software interface. The individual appears to be engaged in a live stream, as indicated by the activity feed on the left side of the screen, showing various usernames and messages such as "Winter_xxx followed your channel" and "my_alienfollowed your channel." The main part of the screen shows a Minecraft scoreboard with different categories like "Overworld," "Nether," "End Portal Search," and "Ender Dragon," along with corresponding scores and a timer reading "2:58.90." The person is seen interacting with the software, possibly adjusting settings or responding to viewer comments. The environment suggests a typical streaming setup with multiple windows open, including a chat window and a list of sources, indicating a complex and interactive streaming session. The atmosphere is focused and dynamic, with the person actively managing the stream and engaging with the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker starting instructions by stating that they will be clicking the plus icon. He describes the window capture feature, asking listeners to create a new window and label it "Live Split". He explains how to choose a window and make sure it has "Live Split" selected. The man states that this will allow the audience to see the "Live Split" window on their stream, explaining the distinction between what is visible on OBS versus the desktop.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a person wearing headphones and a dark-colored shirt is seated in front of a computer screen, which displays a Minecraft scoreboard. The scoreboard shows various statistics related to the game, including the time taken to complete different tasks such as "Overworld," "Nether," "End Portal Search," and "Ender Dragon." The times are displayed in red, with the "Ender Dragon" task showing a time of 2:58.90. The person appears to be engaged in a gaming session, possibly streaming or recording their gameplay. The background of the screen is dark, with the scoreboard and other game-related information clearly visible. The person's facial expressions and gestures suggest they are actively involved in the game, possibly reacting to the gameplay or discussing the statistics shown on the screen. The overall atmosphere is focused and immersive, with the person fully engaged in their gaming experience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker describing how changing the window size of LightSplit on his desktop changes the window itself in OBS, implying a convenient way to change dimensions for OBS. He speaks in an informative, slightly technical tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing headphones and a dark-colored sweater, seated in front of a computer screen displaying a Minecraft Java Edition server status. The server is titled "Any% Random Seed," with various tasks listed, including "Overworld," "Nether," "End Portal Search," and "Ender Dragon," each with corresponding completion times. The person appears to be interacting with the server settings, as indicated by the open "Edit Server" window and the "Previous Segment" text visible on the screen. The background shows a dark-themed desktop with several icons and folders, and the taskbar at the bottom displays various applications. The person's facial expressions and gestures suggest they are explaining or discussing the server's status and settings. The video captures the person's interaction with the server settings, including the use of a color picker to change the server's background color to green, and the appearance of a chat window with notifications of followers. The video concludes with the person continuing to interact with the server settings, with the server status and completion times remaining visible on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a single male speaker explaining a workaround in LiveSplit for a transparent look. He sounds informative and instructional. The speaker mentions "edit layout," "layout settings," and changing background color, giving specific recommendations for colors to use. Then he goes on to "previous segment" and "vertical" as well as "opacity." This is followed by music of an electronic style, presumably from a streamer setup, playing in the background, mixed with speech in the foreground. The speaker shifts from discussing LiveSplit to explaining filters and chroma key, noting the automatic default of green but again suggesting custom color options. He notes that "green was too similar" to "icons that we already have" and mentions icons are "green screened."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a person is seen sitting in front of a computer screen, wearing headphones and holding a microphone, indicating they are likely recording or streaming. The screen displays a Minecraft Java Edition seed tracker with a green background, showing various statistics such as "Overworld," "Nether," "End Portal Search," and "Ender Dragon," along with their respective times. The text "Any% Random Seed" is visible at the top, suggesting the player is tracking their progress in a speedrun. The person appears to be interacting with the seed tracker, as a context menu is visible, indicating they are selecting an option. The environment is a typical computer setup with a dark theme, and the atmosphere seems focused on gaming and content creation. The person's facial expressions and gestures suggest they are engaged in the activity, possibly explaining or reacting to the game's progress.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker gives instructions, advising the listener to right-click, click "save splits," and then "save layout." He emphasizes that doing so will prevent resets in LiveSplit, maintaining progress. The speaker sounds instructional and reassuring.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person wearing a dark blue shirt and headphones, speaking into a microphone in a room illuminated by pink and blue neon lights. The background features a plant and a glowing lamp, creating a cozy atmosphere. A text overlay appears on the right side of the screen, displaying social media handles and a call to action: "Subscribe if you see this" followed by links to YouTube, Twitch, and Twitter, all associated with the username "LiquidCandy." The scene transitions to a series of bold, pixelated "SUBSCRIBE" messages against solid red, blue, green, and pink backgrounds, emphasizing the call to action. The video maintains a consistent theme of encouraging viewers to subscribe to the content creator's channels.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with an upbeat, electronic music piece, creating an energetic mood with synthesizers and a driving rhythm. This transitions into a male speaker who begins by encouraging viewers to like, comment, and learn more. He expresses gratitude and directs listeners to his Twitch and YouTube channels for more content before thanking them again and announcing the end of the video. The clip concludes by returning to the upbeat electronic music, sustaining the initial energetic mood.
